description: Saitama is a hero who only became a hero for fun. After three years of “special training,” he’s become so strong that he’s practically invincible. In fact, he’s too strong—even his mightiest opponents are taken out with a single punch. Now, the great seer Madame Shibabawa’s prediction about the Earth being doomed seems to be coming true as the frequency of monster incidents escalates. Alongside Genos, his faithful disciple, Saitama begins his official hero duties as a member of the Hero Association, while Garou, a man utterly fascinated by monsters, makes his appearance.
synonyms: วันพันช์แมน ภาคที่ 2

tags.name: Superhero
tags.description: Prominently features super-powered humans who aim to serve the greater good.

tags.name: Urban
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a city.

tags.name: Super Power
tags.description: Prominently features characters with special abilities that allow them to do what would normally be physically or logically impossible.

tags.name: Parody
tags.description: Features deliberate exaggeration of popular tropes or a particular genre to comedic effect.

tags.name: Satire
tags.description: Prominently features the use of comedy or ridicule to expose and criticise social phenomena.

tags.name: Cyborg
tags.description: Prominently features a human character whose physiological functions are aided or enhanced by artificial means.

tags.name: Primarily Male Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of male characters.

tags.name: Anti-Hero
tags.description: Features a protagonist who lacks conventional heroic attributes and may be considered a borderline villain.

tags.name: Primarily Adult Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters above a high school age.

tags.name: Surreal Comedy
tags.description: Prominently features comedic moments that defy casual reasoning, resulting in illogical events.

tags.name: Urban Fantasy
tags.description: Set in a world similar to the real world, but with the existence of magic or other supernatural elements.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Martial Arts
tags.description: Centers around the use of traditional hand-to-hand combat.

tags.name: Video Games
tags.description: Centers around characters playing video games.

name.native: イケメン仮面アマイマスク
タンクトップタイガー
タンクトップマスター

node.description:
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/NEBU_KURO)

He was once the assistant and apprentice of Takeshi Obata of _Hikaru no Go_ and _Death Note_ fame. He had a number of one-shots published in Weekly Shonen Jump, namely _Partner_ (won the 122nd Hop*Step award), _Samui Hanashi_ (won the 2nd Prize in the 51st Akatsuka Award), _Kaitou COLT_, and of course, _Eyeshield 21_ (began serialization in Weekly Shonen Jump No. 34 2002).

He is also responsible for designing Dust Man from _Rockman 4_ and Crystal Man from _Rockman 5_.

**[Twitter](https://twitter.com/ONE_rakugaki)** | **[Website](http://galaxyheavyblow.web.fc2.com/)**

One (often stylized as ONE) is a manga artist, best known as the author and creator of [One-Punch Man](https://anilist.co/manga/85364/One-Punch-Man/) and [Mob Psycho 100](https://anilist.co/manga/85189/Mob-Psycho-100/).

He grew up in Konosu, Saitama, and started getting interested in manga when his parents bought him [Crayon Shin-chan](https://anilist.co/manga/32435/Crayon-Shinchan/). ONE also made several manga in the past that never got serialized such as "Sun Man" and "Tennis Player Ryu".

ONE started releasing One-Punch Man on his own website under no official publisher. [A web version](https://anilist.co/manga/74347/One-PunchMan/) was later serialized by Weekly Young Jump with [Yusuke Murata](https://anilist.co/staff/96903/Yusuke-Murata) as the artist. Mob Psycho 100 was serialized in Ura Sunday, the online version of Weekly Shonen Sunday.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/2256470167)

After graduating from high school, Kubota went through training at [Toei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/18/)'s research center before dropping out and joining [Xebec](https://anilist.co/studio/27/) in 1998. Three years later in he met [Sushio](https://anilist.co/staff/103619/) at Comiket, which led to Kubota joining [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/). There he made his debut as an animation director on the premiere of [Mahoromatic](https://anilist.co/anime/277/)'s second season.

In 2005, he made his debut as a character designer, although still jointly together with Sushio and [Takaaki Yamashita](https://anilist.co/staff/110187/), on the 6th [One Piece](https://anilist.co/anime/464/) movie. The film was directed by Mamoru Hosoda, which led to Kubota getting an invite to join the production of [The Girl Who Leapt Through Time](https://anilist.co/anime/2236/) as an animation director. After this he kept working at Gainax until going freelance.

In 2012, he worked as the main character designer on [From the New World](https://anilist.co/anime/13125/) and [Robotics;Notes](https://anilist.co/anime/13599/), and a few years later he served as one on [One-Punch Man](https://anilist.co/anime/21087/), which earned him international fame.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/makoto_myzk) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/宮崎誠)

A music creator for the creative music unit [(K)NoW_NAME](https://anilist.co/staff/126602/).
Kazuo Takigawa is an animator, character designer and storyboard artist.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/TkashiWatanabe)

Joined Top Craft as an animator while still attending university, switched his focus to directing in the late '80s.

Married to [Miyata Naomi](https://anilist.co/staff/220081/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/jumpaoki) | [Pixiv](https://www.pixiv.net/en/users/62166972)

Affiliated with [J.C. Staff](https://anilist.co/studio/7/), where he is one of the studio's leading animators. He is currently the leader of the action animation department at J.C. Staff.

Affiliated with [J.C. Staff](https://anilist.co/studio/7/).

Sakurabi made his directional debut with [Gunparade March](https://anilist.co/anime/266/). He is a fan of simple and refreshing love stories. As a director he's known for modifying original stories a lot, which has brought him substantial amounts of critique. He is quite infamous for his work as the director of the [Tsukihime](https://anilist.co/anime/169/) adaptation, with most fans disapproving of his changes from the original visual novel.

Amongst his most notable directorial works are [Yomigaeru Sora: Rescue Wings](https://anilist.co/anime/798/) and [Flying Witch](https://anilist.co/anime/21284/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/YooheySuzuki) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/鈴木洋平_(アニメ演出家))

Youhei Suzuki is a director and former director of photography formerly working for [J.C.Staff](https://anilist.co/studio/7/JC-Staff). Currently freelance.

Not to be confused with the producer of the same name Youhei Suzuki (鈴木洋平).

Affiliated with [J.C. Staff](https://anilist.co/studio/7/).

More recently she has also been involved in storyboarding and episode directing.
